quotes.topic_title: Driver safety and motorcycle taxi mafia threats
quotes.text: So you would have these areas that are essentially controlled through violence by specific area mafia.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Highlights the on-the-ground reality that marketplace expansion can run into territorial, non-market power structures that must be planned for operationally.

quotes.topic_title: Driver safety and motorcycle taxi mafia threats
quotes.text: We've had everything from bricks thrown at our drivers to knives and machetes being brandished at them,
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A concrete example of the severity of risk faced by supply-side workers, underscoring why safety can’t be treated as a secondary concern.

quotes.topic_title: Driver safety and motorcycle taxi mafia threats
quotes.text: and I think it would've been easy for us to say like, "Hey, they're all contractors. They're third parties, let them kind of just sort it out."
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Surfaces the common (but risky) default mindset of offloading responsibility to contractors—setting up a counterpoint to a more operator-led approach.

quotes.topic_title: Driver safety and motorcycle taxi mafia threats
quotes.text: But instead, we actually hired private security.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Actionable operational move: directly invest in protecting supply to maintain marketplace reliability and trust.

quotes.topic_title: Driver safety and motorcycle taxi mafia threats
quotes.text: And so we actually ran a fairly big private security operation for a fairly long time.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Shows that solving core marketplace constraints may require sustained, non-obvious operational capabilities beyond product and growth.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Gojek is infamous for their scrappiness, their unique approach to ops and growth, and as being one of the first and most successful super apps in the world.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights the operating model (scrappiness + ops + growth) and super-app strategy as key levers behind Gojek’s success.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You'll hear all kinds of wild stories about them having to hire a private security team to protect their drivers, having to build their own cash distribution centers to pay their drivers, plus how they won in large part thanks to their early investment in brand, why it's important to do the hard things as a startup.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete examples of doing unscalable, operationally heavy work—and a reminder that early brand investment can be a decisive advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, why super apps are surprisingly overrated and much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A contrarian teaser that challenges the common assumption that becoming a super app is always the optimal strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I use Coda every day to wrangle my newsletter content calendar, my interview notes for podcasts, and to coordinate my sponsors.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of using a single tool as an operational hub across multiple workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: More recently, I actually wrote a whole post on how Coda's product team operates, and within that post, they shared a dozen templates that they use internally to run their product team, including managing the roadmap, their OKR process, getting internal feedback, and essentially their whole product development process is done within Coda.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Specific methodology: using standardized templates to systematize product operations (roadmap, OKRs, feedback) in one place.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If your team's work is spread out across different documents and spreadsheets and a stack of workflow tools, that's why you need Coda.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable diagnostic for tool sprawl as a root cause of inefficiency and coordination issues.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Coda puts data in one centralized location regardless of format, eliminating roadblocks that can slow your team down.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Operational principle: centralize information across formats to reduce friction and unblock execution.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Rows is different. It combines a modern spreadsheet editor, data integrations with APIs and your business tools and a slick sharing experience that turns any spreadsheet into a beautiful interactive website that you'll be proud to share.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Practical model for making spreadsheets more useful: integrate live data + automate + publish as a shareable artifact.

quotes.topic_title: What Gojek is and its scale
quotes.text: So Gojek started as a motorcycle taxi based service.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Highlights the company’s focused starting point—beginning with a single, local wedge before expanding.

quotes.topic_title: What Gojek is and its scale
quotes.text: And so we started with a very local problem and the first product was a on-demand super app, if you will, where you could ask someone on a motorcycle to give you a ride, send a package for you or buy something and deliver it to you.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A practical product strategy: solve a local pain point with a flexible on-demand platform that supports multiple adjacent use cases.

quotes.topic_title: What Gojek is and its scale
quotes.text: This then evolved over the years into a more general on demand consumer super app that also included car drivers and other services ranging from the ones mentioned to grocery deliveries and payments and financial services.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Shows an expansion playbook—layering new supply types and higher-frequency services (like payments) onto an existing network.

quotes.topic_title: What Gojek is and its scale
quotes.text: we have about 2.7 million drivers across Southeast Asia.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Concrete scale metric that helps practitioners calibrate what “platform scale” can look like outside the US.

quotes.topic_title: What Gojek is and its scale
quotes.text: We've completed about 3 billion orders last year, so that's 3 billion orders.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A standout activity metric that underscores the volume potential of super apps in SEA.

quotes.topic_title: Catalog of services and super-app definition
quotes.text: From the point when we had the most services, we had everything from ride hailing to package delivery to food delivery, to grocery deliveries.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Concrete example of how a super-app expands by stacking adjacent, high-frequency logistics and commerce use cases.

quotes.topic_title: Catalog of services and super-app definition
quotes.text: I think at our peak we had something like near 30 different services all in one app.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A specific scale data point that quantifies what “super app” meant operationally for Gojek.

quotes.topic_title: Catalog of services and super-app definition
quotes.text: I think it's like you're officially a super app if your founder can't even remember all the things that you do right now.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Memorable heuristic for recognizing when product scope has expanded beyond easy internal recall—often a signal of complexity tradeoffs.

quotes.topic_title: Catalog of services and super-app definition
quotes.text: I'd love to talk a little bit about my thoughts on super apps at some point during the session because I definitely have some mixed views over it as a product strategy as we've gone through that whole cycle.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Flags a contrarian stance: even after building a super-app, the strategy can have meaningful downsides practitioners should evaluate.

quotes.topic_title: Why super apps are often overrated
quotes.text: All of these things sound great, but in reality, a lot of those benefits don't pan out.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A contrarian warning that the standard super-app pitch often fails in practice despite looking great in strategy decks.

quotes.topic_title: Why super apps are often overrated
quotes.text: And only about 40% of our customers, like 30 or 40% of our customers knew that this product existed.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing that even highly relevant features can have surprisingly low awareness inside a “super app.”

quotes.topic_title: Why super apps are often overrated
quotes.text: I think the insight that we got here was that there kind of needs to be a unifying concept across all of your services within the app for your users to be able to think about your product in a sensible way.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A practical mental model: without a unifying concept, users can’t form a coherent understanding of what the app is for, limiting cross-sell.

quotes.topic_title: Why super apps are often overrated
quotes.text: And so that whole nirvana of lower CAC, higher retention that are all on these great strategy decks often don't pan out because you kind of have to then resell this idea of like, oh, this is another service and that you can use.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Actionable implication: expansion into unrelated services can increase marketing/education burden, undermining the promised CAC/retention benefits.

quotes.topic_title: Why super apps are often overrated
quotes.text: And it also leads to design constraints because there's only so many ways you can display a whole bunch of different services that actually have little to do with each other, which is why when you see super apps today, it's kind of like this giant menu or this giant grid which does limit the design decisions that you can make, which is unfortunate because if you actually, I think it's an unsolved problem at this point.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A product/UX constraint: piling on services forces grid/menu UI patterns and restricts design, making “super app” UX an unsolved challenge.

quotes.topic_title: Brand as a core consumer advantage
quotes.text: I'm a very big believer that the two most important things in a consumer business are product and brand in that order.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A clear prioritization framework for consumer startups: product first, brand second—not an afterthought.

quotes.topic_title: Brand as a core consumer advantage
quotes.text: For the first six months after launching our app, we had only raised about $2 million and our regional competitor had already raised 250. So they had literally more than a hundred times more capital than we have.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing how brand can help an underfunded company compete against massively better-funded rivals.

quotes.topic_title: Brand as a core consumer advantage
quotes.text: I think that great brands create associations in their customer's minds that transcend the typically transactional or utilitarian one that most people have with businesses and they become part of one's identity.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A mental model for what brand actually does: it shifts you from commodity transactions to identity-based loyalty.

quotes.topic_title: Brand as a core consumer advantage
quotes.text: I think one specific area that I think is really important is that you create consistency across all customer touchpoints.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for building brand: focus on end-to-end consistency, not just marketing assets.

quotes.topic_title: Brand as a core consumer advantage
quotes.text: So branding is not just cool logo, cool advertising, fun imagery, but it's really about the impression that a customer or user has with your product and with your business.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A counter to the common misconception that brand equals visuals—reframing it as the total user impression across product and business.

quotes.topic_title: Helmets and jackets as brand distribution
quotes.text: The jackets and helmets piece I think is really, really important for two reasons.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Sets up a simple, reusable framework for evaluating brand tactics by separating recall from value-demonstration.

quotes.topic_title: Helmets and jackets as brand distribution
quotes.text: But what was really powerful was that when people would be seeing these drivers with their jackets and helmets, they would be seeing passengers on the backseat as they were stuck in traffic.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Highlights how brand distribution can double as a live product demo in the customer’s moment of pain.

quotes.topic_title: Helmets and jackets as brand distribution
quotes.text: And so it was like this beautiful combination of one just having that imagery and having that visual everywhere as a reminder of the brand. But more importantly, it was also a physical reminder of the service of what we do and of how we can help you.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Actionable principle: prioritize channels that connect brand assets directly to the service experience, not just awareness.

quotes.topic_title: Helmets and jackets as brand distribution
quotes.text: But there are these opportunities I think, on being able to reinforce the value proposition of your business in a way that is beyond just visual recall.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A mental model for branding: aim for reinforcement of the value proposition, not merely repeated exposure.

quotes.topic_title: Helmets and jackets as brand distribution
quotes.text: They're admittedly quite rare, which is why in my opinion, the laziest kind of branding tends to be the most popular. Just put your name and your copy on a billboard or on a CPM or CPC campaign.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Contrarian take that challenges default marketing spend toward passive awareness and performance ads.

quotes.topic_title: Scrappy ops: cash booths and fighting fraud
quotes.text: And in the early days, we actually had cash booths. So we actually had physical spaces with a vault and cash sitting in the vault where drivers can show up that, oh, this is my driver ID and this is the balance that I have with you. Please give me the cash.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A concrete example of building offline operational infrastructure to solve a missing ecosystem dependency (digital payouts) and keep the marketplace running.

quotes.topic_title: Scrappy ops: cash booths and fighting fraud
quotes.text: But in the early days we just did it ourselves of building essentially a mini at ATM network, which I think even that sounds too fancy of what it was it. Because it was literally a booth with a vault with cash in it.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A scrappy ops methodology: ship the simplest physical workaround that achieves the job-to-be-done before scaling to formal partners and integrations.

quotes.topic_title: Scrappy ops: cash booths and fighting fraud
quotes.text: And so at the time we had to make a decision of like, okay, we need to nip this in the bud and one way that we could have done it, that would've taken time was it really invest in a lot of the technical security aspects of it, but we didn't have the bandwidth to be able to do that.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Highlights a practical tradeoff framework: when resources are constrained, choose interventions that reduce harm fastest rather than ideal long-term fixes.

quotes.topic_title: Scrappy ops: cash booths and fighting fraud
quotes.text: And so we ended up making the decision of actually copying those features.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Counterintuitive anti-fraud tactic: reduce adoption of malicious tools by matching the legitimate value they provide to users.

quotes.topic_title: Scrappy ops: cash booths and fighting fraud
quotes.text: And that actually significantly reduced the number of users on these third party apps just by having this mentality of you can't beat them, then join them.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic for practitioners: sometimes the fastest way to neutralize a threat is to absorb its best UX into the official product.

quotes.topic_title: Doing hard things as a competitive moat
quotes.text: I really don't like the idea of moats.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Contrarian take that challenges the default startup strategy framing around defensibility.

quotes.topic_title: Doing hard things as a competitive moat
quotes.text: And I don't believe that any moats are durable over time. Eventually with enough time all moats can be crossed.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A mental model for long-term competition: assume advantages decay and plan accordingly.

quotes.topic_title: Doing hard things as a competitive moat
quotes.text: And I think one so-called moat that doesn't get talked about enough is the fact that you're able to do hard things because hard things are hard and just simply doing things that are hard, as long as they create value to your customers, actually is a position that makes it harder for your competitors to be able to win over your customers because it's hard to do those things.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Defines “doing hard things that create customer value” as a practical, defensible competitive moat.

quotes.topic_title: Doing hard things as a competitive moat
quotes.text: But instead we actually hired private security.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Concrete example of operationally heavy execution to protect supply-side partners and build loyalty.

quotes.topic_title: Doing hard things as a competitive moat
quotes.text: And so we actually ran a fairly big private security operation for a fairly long time until it became common to have Gojek drivers do all of these things across cities.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Illustrates sustained investment in a non-obvious capability as a wedge for trust and market expansion.

quotes.topic_title: Founder role-swapping and driver empathy
quotes.text: I do think that in the early days you do have to be a lot more operations heavy.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that early-stage “tech” companies may need to win through operations first before scalable product/tech solutions exist.

quotes.topic_title: Founder role-swapping and driver empathy
quotes.text: there are opportunities to make things a lot better just through probably more innovation in operations to kind of kickstart things until you have the more elegant, scalable, technical or product solution.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A practical methodology: use operational innovation as a bridge to unlock customer value while the long-term technical solution is still being built.

quotes.topic_title: Founder role-swapping and driver empathy
quotes.text: as a founder, I do think it's really important to understand the work that needs to be done in order to see what excellence looks like.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Actionable founder advice: do the job yourself to calibrate quality and set a clear bar for hiring and execution.

quotes.topic_title: Founder role-swapping and driver empathy
quotes.text: seeing how bad I am at it allowed me to understand what good looked like.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: personal incompetence can be a diagnostic tool for defining standards and identifying true expertise.

quotes.topic_title: Founder role-swapping and driver empathy
quotes.text: I remember the early days when I actually picked up a customer. It was this lady and she put in her destination as a mall.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A concrete example of founder-led user empathy that later informed product changes like multi-stop support and waiting fees.

quotes.topic_title: Kevin’s path from finance to tech
quotes.text: And after I did that, I decided to take a bet in Indonesian technology because when all of this was happening was around 2010, 2011, and it was starting to see the development of the current technology giants in the US at the time. And I thought that it would be pretty cool if Indonesia ever had a technology industry to be part of it at the ground floor.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A replicable career/venture strategy: place an early bet on an emerging ecosystem and aim to join at the “ground floor.”

quotes.topic_title: Kevin’s path from finance to tech
quotes.text: And so I moved back in 2011 and it was super early. It was really early at the time where the level of talent, the level of funding, the level of product market fit, the number of people who transacted on the internet was also still super low.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Concrete checklist of ecosystem readiness signals (talent, funding, PMF, online transactions) that practitioners can assess when entering a market early.

quotes.topic_title: Kevin’s path from finance to tech
quotes.text: People still saw the internet as a place for chat apps and social media. And so the level of belief that people had in the space at that time was pretty low.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Highlights a contrarian indicator: when mainstream perception limits the internet to “chat apps and social media,” there may be underappreciated opportunity.

quotes.topic_title: Kevin’s path from finance to tech
quotes.text: People didn't think that real businesses and real valuable products could be built, especially be built locally.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Captures a common barrier in emerging markets—skepticism about local tech viability—that founders can exploit by building where others don’t believe.

quotes.topic_title: Kevin’s path from finance to tech
quotes.text: But being able to see that development I think was something that was really important to me because it really shows you what's possible in a very short time.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A mental model for long-term builders: rapid ecosystem change can compress what seems “impossible” into a short timeframe.

quotes.topic_title: Building outside Silicon Valley: tactics and lessons
quotes.text: In the beginning, we were a lot more ops-heavy than tech-heavy. And doing the things that don't scale through other means I think is definitely something that is absolutely necessary if you're building outside of these main technology hubs.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A concrete operating model for emerging-market startups: prioritize operations and non-scalable tactics early to compensate for ecosystem gaps.

quotes.topic_title: Building outside Silicon Valley: tactics and lessons
quotes.text: Another thing I would say is you need to get good at remote work really early.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A clear capability requirement: remote work maturity becomes a competitive advantage when local talent pools are limited.

quotes.topic_title: Building outside Silicon Valley: tactics and lessons
quotes.text: For us, we built an engineering center in Bangalore in 2015, and this allowed us to compete a lot better with the global giants because we had access to a really deep talent market in India at the time, but we were really early in this whole remote work thing because it wasn't common for people in our region, but also globally to have so much talent concentration outside of headquarters.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A specific example of using a remote engineering hub to access world-class talent and compete with global incumbents.

quotes.topic_title: Building outside Silicon Valley: tactics and lessons
quotes.text: And probably the final I would say tip here is don't just copy, because Gojek was not an Uber clone, even though that was kind of how some investors or analysts talk about us, we were focused on a solution that was uniquely an Indonesian phenomenon, the motorcycle taxi driver.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A contrarian warning against cloning Silicon Valley playbooks: differentiation comes from local market primitives.

quotes.topic_title: Building outside Silicon Valley: tactics and lessons
quotes.text: But all of our competitors at the time when they first entered the motorcycle ride hailing space didn't brand their drivers because they came from a car-centric view.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A memorable illustration of how importing assumptions from other markets can cause obvious tactical misses in product/branding.

quotes.topic_title: Southeast Asia market dynamics and hypergrowth
quotes.text: But beyond the macro picture, I think also we've experienced a pretty unique level of pace of adoption for products with great product market fit.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Highlights a key market dynamic: once you hit PMF in SEA, adoption can accelerate unusually fast—useful for go-to-market and scaling expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Southeast Asia market dynamics and hypergrowth
quotes.text: And in 2015, for example, when we launched our app, we grew more than a hundred percent month on month for the first 16, 18 months. So we more than doubled every month for more than a year.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A concrete hypergrowth data point that calibrates what “insane” PMF-driven growth can look like in Indonesia/SEA.

quotes.topic_title: Southeast Asia market dynamics and hypergrowth
quotes.text: But we also have in this region a very young population who are excited to try new things. And so if you find a solution that really resonates with a lot of these common day-to-day problems, the adoption curve is just absolutely insane.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Actionable market insight: focus on high-frequency day-to-day pain points and you can unlock extreme adoption in young, experimentation-friendly markets.

quotes.topic_title: Southeast Asia market dynamics and hypergrowth
quotes.text: They help farmers feed their fish through this IOT smart device that helps measure the amount of fish feed that needs to go into the ponds, but they also then help farmers do things that get financing and also sell their produce out to local or even regional or global markets.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A memorable example of a “closed loop ecosystem” model—product + financing + distribution—applied to a non-obvious vertical (fish farming).

quotes.topic_title: Southeast Asia market dynamics and hypergrowth
quotes.text: And it's a company doing something like a quarter billion dollars in revenue and it's profitable and it's basically a fish farmer, a close loop ecosystem.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Counterintuitive proof that seemingly niche, “off the wall” SEA startups can reach massive scale and profitability quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Life after stepping down from Gojek
quotes.text: I think that building Gojek is by far the most important professional experience and frankly, one of the most important life experiences I've had.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Highlights a practitioner-relevant lens: building a company can be evaluated as a life-shaping experience, not just a career milestone.

quotes.topic_title: Life after stepping down from Gojek
quotes.text: It's made me a way better person actually.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: A memorable reminder that leadership roles can be approached as personal development programs, not only operational challenges.

quotes.topic_title: Life after stepping down from Gojek
quotes.text: And now that I've stepped away, I am not as bored or as aimless as people would expect after having such a kind of all-consuming thing be part of my life experience.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Counterintuitive observation that post-exit life doesn’t have to be empty—even after an all-consuming founder journey.

quotes.topic_title: Life after stepping down from Gojek
quotes.text: Honestly, Lenny, I don't know. I don't have a plan at this stage.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Normalizes uncertainty as a valid transition strategy, especially after intense, long-term leadership roles.

quotes.topic_title: Life after stepping down from Gojek
quotes.text: I think right now I'm just taking things easy and trying to figure out another problem I guess, that I could be obsessed about.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Aluwi
quotes.context: Actionable heuristic for founders: optimize for finding the next “obsession-worthy” problem rather than forcing a rigid plan.
